I like how Rosie Collington in the latest episode of Tech Won't Save Us talks about "capacity lock-in" in governments: everything is outsourced until the government is so slimmed down that it doesn't even have anyone on staff anymore that could evaluate what needs to be done or if the hired contractors that are supposed to deliver government services are able to do what they claim.

The same happens with digital communities that only use free services. The practical knowledge about how to put an image online, how to moderate a discussion, or how to just contact somebody, is lost.

Maybe the term capacity lock-in can be useful when trying to introduce ideas of conviviality into a discussion that is more technical. Esp. open source is often focused on fighting technical lock-in that happens via proprietary data formats and software—essentially stifling the ability of a developer to take their knowledge to the next job—and avoid to be more concrete on the side of how that translates for users. Capacity lock-in seems like a very tangible way to sum up what situations users shouldn't be put into.

https://techwontsave.us/episode/156_the_consequences_of_leaving_tech_to_the_private_sector_w_rosie_collington

title: Thieves’ Cant: The Secret Language Used By Criminals For Centuries

last_post.content:
Fun article on "thieves' cant", the slang code words used by rogues from the 16th to 19th centuries

https://www.ranker.com/list/history-of-cant-secret-language/genevieve-carlton

Apparently the source of several contemporary words including "phony", from "fáinne" (Irish for ring) or "fawney rig", a cheap ring that a con man would sell for an inflated value.

Some more fun examples:
"frummagemmed" - hanged
"chunk o'gin" - diamond
"priggers of cacklers" - hen snatchers
"cackling farts" - eggs

title: After a Decade of Tracking Politicians’ Deleted Tweets, Politwoops Is No More

last_post.content:
After a Decade of Tracking Politicians’ Deleted Tweets, Politwoops Is No More
--
Since Elon Musk took over Twitter, it has disabled the function we used to track the deleted Tweets of elected officials and political candidates — and the new method that Twitter says should identify deleted tweets appears to be broken.

Regardless of one's feelings about Twitter, this is a loss for transparency.

Thanks to @derekwillis for coming back to write this obit.

Did you know that the Independent Games Festival's main prize, the Seumas McNally Grand Prize, is named after the creator of its *second* winner? Seumas made one of the last great shareware games, Tread Marks, a 3D combat racer with deformable terrain, released in early 2000.

Seumas had been diagnosed Hodgkin Lymphoma three years earlier, aged 18. As his health declined, he defiantly made the best Breakout game ever, DX-Ball 2, with help from his family, then after meeting his hero John Carmack he dove into this more ambitious, innovative project.

He released the game on January 3rd, 2000, then accepted the IGF main prize March 10th, assisted by an oxygen tank and seated in a wheelchair. He died 11 days later. Carmack later penned a moving eulogy (see attached images).

In honour of his gamedev dream, his family continued making games under his company name, Longbow Digital Arts (now Longbow Games). They made the Hegemony RTS series and puzzle-platformer Golem. https://longbowgames.com

As my own tribute to Seumas McNally's legacy, and to the brilliance of his games, I told a longer version of his story to close out my new book, Shareware Heroes: The renegades who redefined gaming at the dawn of the internet. More info on the book at https://sharewareheroes.com
